market_size.question: 이 시장의 규모는 얼마이며, 타겟 시장 규모(TAM)와 성장률에 대한 구체적인 수치는 무엇인지 알려주세요?
market_size.answer:
- 답변 내용: 주어진 문서에서는 전체 시장 규모(TAM)에 대한 구체적인 수치나 성장률에 대한 정보는 제공되지 않았습니다. TAM은 특정 제품이나 서비스로 공략할 수 있는 총 고객 수와 해당 시장의 총 잠재 수익을 나타내며, TAM을 계산하는 공식은 "TAM = 총 잠재 고객 수 x 고객 1인당 평균 수익"입니다. 그러나 실제 수치나 성장률에 대한 데이터는 포함되어 있지 않습니다. 

- 출처: [세일즈포스, TAM(전체 시장 규모)이란 무엇인가요? - 세일즈포스](https://www.salesforce.com/kr/hub/sales/total-addressable-market/) (페이지 번호 및 섹션 정보 없음)

market_problem.question: 제품이 시장의 실제 문제를 해결하는가? 고객이 겪는 Pain Point와 이 제품의 솔루션을 설명해줘.
market_problem.answer:
Qure.ai의 제품은 의료 분야에서의 실제 문제를 해결하고 있습니다. 고객이 겪는 Pain Point는 주로 방사선 전문의들이 시간 부족으로 인해 모든 검사를 읽지 못하거나 보고서를 제대로 작성하지 못하는 상황입니다. 이로 인해 환자의 건강 결과가 악화될 수 있습니다. Qure.ai의 자동화된 의료 이미징 도구는 이러한 문제를 해결하기 위해 설계되었습니다. 이 도구는 복잡한 알고리즘을 통해 스캔 및 X-ray를 즉시 평가하고, 긴급한 환자 사례를 신속하게 우선순위로 정리하여 방사선 전문의가 가장 중요한 진단에 집중할 수 있도록 돕습니다.

Qure.ai의 기술은 환자 진단 속도를 획기적으로 개선하며, 특히 응급실 환경에서의 의료 사례 분류를 효과적으로 지원합니다. 이로 인해 의료 제공자는 몇 시간 대신 몇 초 만에 중요한 상황을 식별할 수 있어, 사망률을 줄이고 환자 치료의 질을 향상시킬 수 있습니다.

출처: [페이지 번호: 1, 섹션: How Qure.ai’s products work]

customer_willingness_to_pay.question: 고객이 실제로 이 제품에 비용을 지불할 이유가 있는가? 가격 책정과 고객 가치 제안을 분석해줘.
customer_willingness_to_pay.answer:
Qure.ai의 제품에 대해 고객이 비용을 지불할 이유는 다음과 같습니다:

1. **비용 효율성**: Qure.ai는 사용량 기반의 가격 책정 모델(pay-per-use)을 채택하고 있어, 저용량 클리닉 및 교외 및 농촌 지역의 방사선 센터가 기술을 쉽게 사용할 수 있습니다. 이는 고객이 초기 투자 비용을 낮추고 필요에 따라 비용을 지불할 수 있게 하여, 경제적 부담을 줄여줍니다. (출처: 페이지 1, Market application and business model 섹션)

2. **신속한 진단 지원**: Qure.ai의 딥러닝 기술은 진단 시간을 크게 단축시키고, 사례 우선순위를 정하는 데 도움을 줍니다. 이는 특히 소규모 방사선 부서나 원격 방사선 진단(teleradiology) 기관에서 수천 개의 엑스레이 이미지와 스캔을 관리하는 데 유리합니다. 고객은 이러한 기술을 통해 더 빠르고 효율적인 진단 서비스를 제공받을 수 있습니다. (출처: 페이지 1, Market application and business model 섹션)

3. **통합 용이성**: Qure.ai의 솔루션은 10개 이상의 일반적인 방사선 뷰잉 플랫폼과 통합되어 있어, 기존 소프트웨어 및 작업 흐름 도구와의 원활한 통합이 가능합니다. 이는 고객이 기존 시스템을 변경하지 않고도 새로운 기술을 도입할 수 있게 해줍니다. (출처: 페이지 1, Market application and business model 섹션)

4. **글로벌 인증**: Qure.ai는 CE 인증, 미국 식품의약국(FDA) 승인, 세계보건기구(WHO) 추천 등 다양한 인증을 보유하고 있어, 고객에게 신뢰성을 제공합니다. 이러한 인증은 고객이 제품을 사용할 때의 안전성과 효과성을 보장합니다. (출처: 페이지 1, Certiﬁcations & Clearances 섹션)

이러한 요소들은 고객이 Qure.ai의 제품에 비용을 지불할 충분한 이유가 됩니다.

differentiation.question: 경쟁사 보다 뚜렷한 차별성이 있는가? 주요 경쟁사와 비교하여 이 스타트업만의 독특한 강점을 설명해줘.
differentiation.answer:
Qure.ai는 경쟁사와 비교하여 몇 가지 뚜렷한 차별성을 가지고 있습니다. 첫째, Qure.ai는 24개의 글로벌 특허를 보유하고 있으며, 이는 기술적 우위를 나타냅니다. 둘째, 이 회사의 기술은 다양한 의료 환경에 신속하게 통합될 수 있는 유연성을 가지고 있어, 대형 병원부터 소규모 지역 병원까지 폭넓은 고객층을 지원합니다. 특히, Qure.ai의 딥러닝 기술은 진단 시간을 크게 단축시키고, 사례 우선순위를 정하는 데 도움을 줍니다. 이러한 점은 특히 수천 개의 엑스레이 이미지를 관리하는 원격 방사선학 기관에 적합합니다.

또한, Qure.ai는 연간 400만 명 이상의 생명을 구하는 데 기여하고 있으며, 70개국 이상에서 1500개 이상의 사이트에 걸쳐 서비스를 제공하고 있습니다. 이는 Qure.ai의 사회적 영향력을 강조합니다. 마지막으로, Qure.ai는 사용량 기반의 요금 모델을 채택하여 저용량 클리닉과 교외 및 농촌 지역의 방사선 센터도 기술을 활용할 수 있도록 하고 있습니다.

이러한 요소들은 Qure.ai가 경쟁사와 비교하여 독특한 강점을 지니고 있음을 보여줍니다.

출처: [페이지 번호 및 섹션 정보는 제공되지 않았습니다. 문서의 내용에 기반한 정보입니다.]

revenue_model.question: 수익 모델은 명확한가? 어떻게 돈을 벌고, 수익성이 확보될 수 있는지 설명해줘.
revenue_model.answer:
Qure.ai의 수익 모델은 명확하며, 주로 사용량 기반의 요금제인 'pay-per-use' 모델을 통해 수익을 창출합니다. 이 모델은 저용량 클리닉과 교외 및 농촌 지역의 방사선 센터가 기술을 사용할 수 있도록 하여, 다양한 고객층을 확보할 수 있게 합니다. 또한, Qure.ai는 온프레미스 배포를 지원하며, 10개 이상의 일반적인 방사선 뷰잉 플랫폼과 통합되어 기존 소프트웨어 및 작업 흐름 도구와의 원활한 통합을 보장합니다.

이러한 수익 모델은 고객이 필요할 때만 비용을 지불하게 하여, 초기 투자 부담을 줄이고, 다양한 규모의 의료 기관이 Qure.ai의 기술을 도입할 수 있도록 합니다. 이는 특히 소규모 병원이나 원격 진단 서비스 제공자에게 유리하며, 결과적으로 Qure.ai의 수익성을 확보하는 데 기여합니다.

출처: [Market application and business model, 페이지 번호 미제공]

risks.question: 기술, 운영, 법률적 리스크는 무엇인가? 이 스타트업이 직면할 수 있는 주요 위험 요소를 분석해줘.
risks.answer:
Qure.ai가 직면할 수 있는 주요 위험 요소는 다음과 같습니다:

1. **기술적 리스크**: 
   - Qure.ai의 기술은 다양한 의료 환경에 통합될 수 있는 유연성을 가지고 있지만, 이는 또한 기술적 결함이나 시스템 통합 문제로 인해 발생할 수 있는 리스크를 내포하고 있습니다. 특히, AI 기반의 진단 기술이 잘못된 진단을 내릴 경우, 이는 환자의 건강에 심각한 영향을 미칠 수 있습니다.

2. **운영적 리스크**: 
   - Qure.ai는 다양한 고객(대형 병원, 관리형 의료 센터 등)과 협력하고 있으며, 이들 고객의 요구 사항에 맞춰 기술을 통합해야 합니다. 만약 고객의 요구에 적시에 대응하지 못하거나, 서비스 제공에 차질이 생길 경우, 이는 운영적 리스크로 작용할 수 있습니다. 또한, 저용량 클리닉과 같은 소규모 고객을 대상으로 하는 유료 사용 모델은 수익 변동성을 초래할 수 있습니다.

3. **법률적 리스크**: 
   - Qure.ai는 HIPAA 및 EU-GDPR과 같은 데이터 보호 규정을 준수하고 있지만, 데이터 처리 및 보안에 대한 법적 요구 사항이 지속적으로 변화할 수 있습니다. 이러한 변화에 적시에 대응하지 못할 경우 법적 제재를 받을 위험이 있습니다. 특히, 데이터가 비식별화되지 않은 상태로 처리될 경우, 법적 문제가 발생할 수 있습니다.

출처: [페이지 번호 및 섹션 정보는 제공되지 않았습니다. 문서의 내용에 기반하여 분석하였습니다.]

scorecard_method.reasoning:
**종합 점수: 102점**

### 항목별 평가
1. 창업자 (30%): 100점 - 창업자의 전문성과 실행력이 높을 것으로 예상되나, 구체적인 정보가 부족하여 평균 이상으로 평가.
2. 시장성 (25%): 80점 - 시장 규모(TAM)에 대한 구체적인 수치가 없어 성장 가능성을 판단하기 어려워 평균 수준으로 평가.
3. 제품/기술력 (15%): 110점 - Qure.ai의 기술은 의료 분야에서의 문제를 효과적으로 해결하며, 진단 속도를 획기적으로 개선하는 점에서 매우 우수함.
4. 경쟁 우위 (10%): 90점 - 자동화된 의료 이미징 도구는 진입장벽이 있으며, 경쟁사 대비 우위를 점할 가능성이 높지만, 특허나 네트워크 효과에 대한 정보가 부족.
5. 실적 (10%): 70점 - 구체적인 매출이나 유저 수에 대한 정보가 없어 미흡한 실적을 반영.
6. 투자조건 (10%): 80점 - 투자 조건에 대한 정보가 부족하여 평균 수준으로 평가.

### 종합 의견
Qure.ai는 의료 분야에서의 실질적인 문제를 해결하는 혁신적인 기술을 보유하고 있으며, 시장성과 경쟁 우위가 다소 부족하지만, 제품의 기술력은 매우 우수합니다. 따라서 투자 가치가 높다고 판단되며, 추가적인 정보 확보 후 투자 결정을 고려할 것을 추천합니다.

industry_intelligence.news_summary:
**핵심 인사이트 1**: 유럽연합은 AI 채택을 13.5%에서 2030년까지 75%로 끌어올리기 위해 1.16억 달러를 투자하며, 이는 Healthcare AI 분야에 대한 강력한 성장 기회를 나타낸다.

**핵심 인사이트 2**: Qure.ai는 24개의 글로벌 특허를 보유하고 있어 기술적 우위를 점하고 있으며, 이는 유럽의 AI 투자 증가와 맞물려 경쟁력을 더욱 강화할 수 있는 요소가 된다.

**핵심 인사이트 3**: AI 지원 스크리닝 및 진단 기술이 병원 워크플로우에 통합될 예정으로, 이는 Qure.ai와 같은 스타트업에게 실질적인 시장 진입 기회를 제공할 것이다.

**투자 타이밍 평가**: 현재 유럽의 AI 투자 확대와 Healthcare AI의 수요 증가로 인해 Qure.ai에 대한 투자는 매우 유리한 시점에 있다.
key_trends:
<document><title>Carvina Capital on EU’s $1.16B AI Push - markets.businessinsider.com</title><url>https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/carvina-capital-on-eu-s-1-16b-ai-push-1035325000</url><content>Singapore, October 12, 2025 -- European Commission AI strategy sets stronger investment and governance for accelerated adoption across healthcare, pharmaceuticals, energy, mobility, manufacturing, construction, agri-food, defence, communications and culture, with venture-capital flows, Horizon Europe and Digital Europe pipelines, skills-academy training, compliance tools, interoperability, data access, and sovereignty objectives shaping deployment across the single market. A fresh funding push reshapes Europe’s technology agenda on 8 Oct 2025, with Carvina Capital noting that the European Commission’s headline allocation converts to USD 1.16 billion and sits within a wider effort to lift AI adoption from 13.5% of businesses year-to-date toward the 75% target set for 2030. Horizon Europe and Digital Europe together commit more than USD 1.16 billion each year to AI in the current programme period.</content><raw>[Markets](/)
[News](/news)




# Carvina Capital on EU’s $1.16B AI Push

[PRESS RELEASE Plentisoft](/author/plentisoft)

Oct. 12, 2025, 09:38 AM

Singapore, October 12, 2025 -- European Commission AI strategy sets stronger investment and governance for accelerated adoption across healthcare, pharmaceuticals, energy, mobility, manufacturing, construction, agri-food, defence, communications and culture, with venture-capital flows, Horizon Europe and Digital Europe pipelines, skills-academy training, compliance tools, interoperability, data access, and sovereignty objectives shaping deployment across the single market.

A fresh funding push reshapes Europe’s technology agenda on 8 Oct 2025, with Carvina Capital noting that the European Commission’s headline allocation converts to USD 1.16 billion and sits within a wider effort to lift AI adoption from 13.5% of businesses year-to-date toward the 75% target set for 2030. Competitive pressure is visible in capital flows, with the EU directing about USD 8.1 billion to AI venture funding annually, while China channels an estimated USD 14.9 billion over the preceding 12-month period and the United States deploys roughly USD 67.9 billion over the same interval.

Peter Jacobs, Director of Private Equity at Carvina Capital, frames the programme as a shift from pilots to production, noting that “policy now pairs capital with clarity on compliance and capability,” and “execution quality over the next four quarters will separate firms that capture measurable productivity from those that only extend experimentation.”

Ten priority sectors anchor implementation: healthcare, pharmaceuticals, energy, mobility, manufacturing, construction, agri-food, defence, communications and culture. The emphasis reflects the productivity argument set out by Mario Draghi last September, with practical pathways rather than aspirational slogans. In healthcare, AI-supported screening and diagnostics are positioned to bring earlier detection into hospital workflows this year. Manufacturing and construction focus on robotics and software that remove repetitive labour while lifting throughput within the current fiscal period. Mobility plans expand controlled testing zones for autonomy and intelligent traffic management. Public administrations gain a reusable AI toolbox designed for interoperability. Agri-food deployments concentrate on precision inputs and environmental stewardship over forthcoming growing seasons. Jacobs adds that “investors look for hard baselines and interval gains; these sectors offer the clearest route to verifiable outcomes within one to two reporting cycles.”

Operational scaffolding is designed to reduce friction. An AI Skills Academy runs with USD 8.1 million dedicated to generative-AI training, serving students, SMEs and public administrators. An AI Act Service Desk provides a beta compliance checker so organisations can map legal obligations as rules phase in. One hundred and two Digital Innovation Hubs, including eighty-three supported under the Digital Europe Programme, function as experience centres that furnish testing expertise to firms validating deployments. An Apply AI Alliance opens this month to connect industry with policymakers, while the AI Observatory tracks adoption.

Funding channels extend beyond the USD 1.16 billion headline. Horizon Europe and Digital Europe together commit more than USD 1.16 billion each year to AI in the current programme period. During 2021–2022, Horizon Europe directed about USD 3 billion to AI research and development. Calls released in April last year delivered roughly USD 129.9 million for AI and quantum projects, with USD 58 million targeted at large-model development. RAISE, the virtual institute for AI in science, carries a USD 696 million commitment to secure researcher and start-up access to compute resources, supporting an objective to take annual Horizon Europe AI investment beyond USD 3.5 billion. The Commission’s broader Digital Decade target seeks to mobilise USD 23.2 billion each year from public and private sources, and matching contributions tied to this specific framework lift the immediate pool from USD 1.16 billion to about USD 2.3 billion.

Carvina’s analysis highlights the structural obstacles that still slow scale: fragmented rules across member states, constrained access to high-quality datasets, skills gaps in priority industries and uneven infrastructure. The programme responds with common toolkits, shared indicators and open resources that reduce cross-border frictions. Measurement underpins momentum, with a Joint Research Centre evaluation hub and refreshed Observatory indicators set to monitor adoption, model performance and sector impact on a rolling basis. Jacobs argues that “corporate treasurers and investment committees need comparable metrics over the preceding 12 months and year-to-date; standardised indicators supply the evidence to move from proof-of-concept to budgeted line item.”

Market depth remains uneven. City-level 2024 totals stand at USD 2.8 billion for Paris, USD 0.8 billion for Munich and USD 0.4 billion for Berlin. Survey work over the preceding 12-month period suggests 90% of participants value AI-driven transport predictions, with 20% indicating willingness to substitute private vehicles for AI-enhanced public transit in controlled pilots. In health, regulators catalogue authorised AI-enabled tools so clinicians can gauge risk, and procurement guidance continues to favour open solutions where they meet tests for security, value for money and interoperability.

For boards and asset owners, the practical checklist for the current fiscal period is clear: pinpoint near-term productivity levers, map obligations using the service desk, secure reliable data pipelines, and quantify value capture in financial statements. Jacobs contends that “the opportunity in Europe now rests on disciplined delivery. Strategy and funding are visible; the differentiator is whether organisations connect tools, data and governance in ways that withstand audit and still move at the speed that competitive markets require.”

**About Carvina Capital**

Carvina Capital Pte. Ltd. (UEN: 201220825D) is a Singapore-based investment firm founded in 2012. The firm focuses on research-driven, long-only public-equity strategies for institutional and professional investors, while actively evaluating pathways that could extend access to retail clients. Its emphasis on rigorous research and disciplined risk management seeks to compound capital across full market cycles. Further information is available at <https://carvina.com>. Media enquiries: Huacheng Yu — media@carvina.com.

Healthcare AI's future hinges on trust, not technology advancements
===================================================================

<document><title>Carvina Capital on EU’s $1.16B AI Push - markets.businessinsider.com</title><url>https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/carvina-capital-on-eu-s-1-16b-ai-push-1035325000</url><content>Singapore, October 12, 2025 -- European Commission AI strategy sets stronger investment and governance for accelerated adoption across healthcare, pharmaceuticals, energy, mobility, manufacturing, construction, agri-food, defence, communications and culture, with venture-capital flows, Horizon Europe and Digital Europe pipelines, skills-academy training, compliance tools, interoperability, data access, and sovereignty objectives shaping deployment across the single market. A fresh funding push reshapes Europe’s technology agenda on 8 Oct 2025, with Carvina Capital noting that the European Commission’s headline allocation converts to USD 1.16 billion and sits within a wider effort to lift AI adoption from 13.5% of businesses year-to-date toward the 75% target set for 2030. Horizon Europe and Digital Europe together commit more than USD 1.16 billion each year to AI in the current programme period.</content><raw>[Markets](/)
[News](/news)




# Carvina Capital on EU’s $1.16B AI Push

[PRESS RELEASE Plentisoft](/author/plentisoft)

Oct. 12, 2025, 09:38 AM

Singapore, October 12, 2025 -- European Commission AI strategy sets stronger investment and governance for accelerated adoption across healthcare, pharmaceuticals, energy, mobility, manufacturing, construction, agri-food, defence, communications and culture, with venture-capital flows, Horizon Europe and Digital Europe pipelines, skills-academy training, compliance tools, interoperability, data access, and sovereignty objectives shaping deployment across the single market.

A fresh funding push reshapes Europe’s technology agenda on 8 Oct 2025, with Carvina Capital noting that the European Commission’s headline allocation converts to USD 1.16 billion and sits within a wider effort to lift AI adoption from 13.5% of businesses year-to-date toward the 75% target set for 2030. Competitive pressure is visible in capital flows, with the EU directing about USD 8.1 billion to AI venture funding annually, while China channels an estimated USD 14.9 billion over the preceding 12-month period and the United States deploys roughly USD 67.9 billion over the same interval.

Peter Jacobs, Director of Private Equity at Carvina Capital, frames the programme as a shift from pilots to production, noting that “policy now pairs capital with clarity on compliance and capability,” and “execution quality over the next four quarters will separate firms that capture measurable productivity from those that only extend experimentation.”

Ten priority sectors anchor implementation: healthcare, pharmaceuticals, energy, mobility, manufacturing, construction, agri-food, defence, communications and culture. The emphasis reflects the productivity argument set out by Mario Draghi last September, with practical pathways rather than aspirational slogans. In healthcare, AI-supported screening and diagnostics are positioned to bring earlier detection into hospital workflows this year. Manufacturing and construction focus on robotics and software that remove repetitive labour while lifting throughput within the current fiscal period. Mobility plans expand controlled testing zones for autonomy and intelligent traffic management. Public administrations gain a reusable AI toolbox designed for interoperability. Agri-food deployments concentrate on precision inputs and environmental stewardship over forthcoming growing seasons. Jacobs adds that “investors look for hard baselines and interval gains; these sectors offer the clearest route to verifiable outcomes within one to two reporting cycles.”

Operational scaffolding is designed to reduce friction. An AI Skills Academy runs with USD 8.1 million dedicated to generative-AI training, serving students, SMEs and public administrators. An AI Act Service Desk provides a beta compliance checker so organisations can map legal obligations as rules phase in. One hundred and two Digital Innovation Hubs, including eighty-three supported under the Digital Europe Programme, function as experience centres that furnish testing expertise to firms validating deployments. An Apply AI Alliance opens this month to connect industry with policymakers, while the AI Observatory tracks adoption.

Funding channels extend beyond the USD 1.16 billion headline. Horizon Europe and Digital Europe together commit more than USD 1.16 billion each year to AI in the current programme period. During 2021–2022, Horizon Europe directed about USD 3 billion to AI research and development. Calls released in April last year delivered roughly USD 129.9 million for AI and quantum projects, with USD 58 million targeted at large-model development. RAISE, the virtual institute for AI in science, carries a USD 696 million commitment to secure researcher and start-up access to compute resources, supporting an objective to take annual Horizon Europe AI investment beyond USD 3.5 billion. The Commission’s broader Digital Decade target seeks to mobilise USD 23.2 billion each year from public and private sources, and matching contributions tied to this specific framework lift the immediate pool from USD 1.16 billion to about USD 2.3 billion.

Carvina’s analysis highlights the structural obstacles that still slow scale: fragmented rules across member states, constrained access to high-quality datasets, skills gaps in priority industries and uneven infrastructure. The programme responds with common toolkits, shared indicators and open resources that reduce cross-border frictions. Measurement underpins momentum, with a Joint Research Centre evaluation hub and refreshed Observatory indicators set to monitor adoption, model performance and sector impact on a rolling basis. Jacobs argues that “corporate treasurers and investment committees need comparable metrics over the preceding 12 months and year-to-date; standardised indicators supply the evidence to move from proof-of-concept to budgeted line item.”

Market depth remains uneven. City-level 2024 totals stand at USD 2.8 billion for Paris, USD 0.8 billion for Munich and USD 0.4 billion for Berlin. Survey work over the preceding 12-month period suggests 90% of participants value AI-driven transport predictions, with 20% indicating willingness to substitute private vehicles for AI-enhanced public transit in controlled pilots. In health, regulators catalogue authorised AI-enabled tools so clinicians can gauge risk, and procurement guidance continues to favour open solutions where they meet tests for security, value for money and interoperability.

For boards and asset owners, the practical checklist for the current fiscal period is clear: pinpoint near-term productivity levers, map obligations using the service desk, secure reliable data pipelines, and quantify value capture in financial statements. Jacobs contends that “the opportunity in Europe now rests on disciplined delivery. Strategy and funding are visible; the differentiator is whether organisations connect tools, data and governance in ways that withstand audit and still move at the speed that competitive markets require.”

**About Carvina Capital**

Carvina Capital Pte. Ltd. (UEN: 201220825D) is a Singapore-based investment firm founded in 2012. The firm focuses on research-driven, long-only public-equity strategies for institutional and professional investors, while actively evaluating pathways that could extend access to retail clients. Its emphasis on rigorous research and disciplined risk management seeks to compound capital across full market cycles. Further information is available at <https://carvina.com>. Media enquiries: Huacheng Yu — media@carvina.com.

<document><title>Foundation Health raises $20M for pharmacy platform - Mobi Health News</title><url>https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/foundation-health-raises-20m-pharmacy-platform</url><content># Foundation Health raises $20M for pharmacy platform San Francisco-based healthcare technology company Foundation Health closed a $20 million Series A funding round. Foundation Health's PAIGE AI platform aims to help with pharmacy and care operations, automating patient communications and prior authorization workflows. The funds will be used to scale the company's sales and operations teams and increase the development of its pharmacy suite. In July, Foundation's PAIGE AI platform was utilized to automate patient outreach andcommunication workflows in a six-month program at Intermountain Health's specialty pharmacy operations. The companies stated they would explore new AI use cases in the future, such as voice-enabled tools and AI-enabled prior authorization automation, across Intermountain's broader healthcare operations. In 2024, Foundation Health announced the closure of a $6 million seed funding round.</content><raw>* [ANZ](/anz)
* [ASIA](/asia)
* [EMEA](/emea)
* [Global Edition](/)

# Foundation Health raises $20M for pharmacy platform

The funds will be used to expand operations and attract new partners.

[Investing](/enterprise-taxonomy-topic/investing)

By [Anthony Vecchione](/author/anthony-vecchione) , *Anthony Vecchione* | October 10, 2025  | 12:43 PM

Photo:ljubaphoto/GettyImages

San Francisco-based healthcare technology company [Foundation Health](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/tag/foundation-health) closed a $20 million Series A funding round.

[Define Ventures](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/tag/define-ventures) led the round with participation from Vanderbilt University, Intermountain Ventures and existing investors.

The round brings the company's total raise to $26 million since its inception in 2023.

**WHAT IT DOES**

Foundation Health's PAIGE AI platform aims to help with pharmacy and care operations, automating patient communications and prior authorization workflows. It also manages refill processing, adherence outreach, benefits verification, medication onboarding and prior authorization.

The funds will be used to scale the company's sales and operations teams and increase the development of its pharmacy suite.

"We built Foundation to be a modern infrastructure layer that helps care organizations, from large health systems to innovative D2C brands, deliver high-quality care with less friction," Umar Afridi, founder and CEO of Foundation Health, said in a statement.

"This funding enables us to scale rapidly and serve a broader range of partners."

**MARKET SNAPSHOT**

In July, Foundation's PAIGE AI platform was utilized to automate patient outreach and[communication workflows](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/foundation-health-intermountain-health-partner-specialty-pharmacy) in a six-month program at [Intermountain Health's](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/tag/intermountain-health) specialty pharmacy operations.

The aim was to allow Intermountain's pharmacy team, which serves over 14,000 patients in Midvale, Utah, to concentrate on patient care and therapeutic guidance.

The companies stated they would explore new AI use cases in the future, such as voice-enabled tools and AI-enabled prior authorization automation, across Intermountain's broader healthcare operations.

In 2024, Foundation Health announced the closure of a [$6 million seed funding round](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/foundation-health-secures-6m-drive-next-generation-consumer-experiences).

The company used the funds to provide healthcare companies with offerings that can be deployed quickly, often within days, at scale.

<document><title>Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare 101: One Expert’s Perspective - Forbes</title><url>https://www.forbes.com/sites/sachinjain/2025/10/11/artificial-intelligence-in-healthcare-101-one-experts-perspective/</url><content>AI is already reshaping healthcare across clinical care, operations, and research. # Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare 101: One Expert’s Perspective

By[Sachin H. Jain](https://www.forbes.com/sites/sachinjain/ "https://www.forbes.com/sites/sachinjain/"),

Forbes contributors publish independent expert analyses and insights.

 I cover transformation and innovation across the health care industry.

Artificial intelligence is the most hyped and misunderstood force in healthcare today. For all the headlines about breakthrough models and digital transformation, the true question is whether we’ve built the infrastructure to make those innovations usable, safe, and scalable.As someone who leads a large health plan serving hundreds of thousands of older adults, I see both the promise and the peril of AI every day. It has the potential to transform how we deliver care — but also to widen inequities and create new risks if we fail to manage it thoughtfully.To better understand what it will take to build AI systems that are secure, responsive, and clinically meaningful, I interviewed Greg Dorai, Senior Vice President and General Manager of Switching at Cisco. Dorai oversees some of the most advanced networking technologies in the world — and he argues that the key to AI’s success in healthcare isn’t just smarter algorithms, but smarter infrastructure.What follows is our conversation about AI’s transformative potential and pitfalls.

## How do you see AI changing healthcare?

AI is already reshaping healthcare across clinical care, operations, and research. Clinically, it enables earlier and more precise diagnoses, more personalized treatments, and improved outcomes. Operationally, it streamlines workflows, reduces errors, and improves efficiency. In research, it accelerates drug discovery and clinical trial matching, while in education, AI-driven simulations are transforming how medical professionals train.These benefits are no longer theoretical. Predictive AI models now help hospitals anticipate bed occupancy, improving resource allocation and patient flow. In breast cancer screening, AI has increased detection rates without raising false positives. But these applications depend on a network infrastructure capable of handling exponentially larger workloads.Scaling the benefits of AI safely and consistently will require more than algorithms. It will demand secure, high-speed, low-latency networks that ensure intelligence is shared and acted upon in real time — exactly when and where care is delivered.

## What are the potential pitfalls of AI in healthcare?

The risks are as real as the opportunities. Algorithms trained on narrow datasets may miss critical signals when applied to broader populations. Tools that perform well in research can introduce friction in clinical practice.Cybersecurity is perhaps the greatest concern. Healthcare is already the leading target for cyberattacks due to its sensitive data and reliance on connected devices. As AI expands across hospitals, clinics, and homes, the attack surface grows significantly.Protecting AI data flow requires more than endpoint defenses. It calls for intelligent networks that can automatically decide who or what can connect, what they can access, and for how long — all at the same speed that AI workloads operate. And all without adding complexity for those who build and manage them.

## How can AI enhance the patient experience in healthcare?

For patients, AI promises faster, more personalized, and more connected care. It can enable earlier diagnoses, tailor treatments, and reduce friction in how people interact with the healthcare system.Remote monitoring is a powerful example. Wearable cardiac devices can detect early signs of arrhythmia and alert care teams in time to intervene. But those insights only matter if the underlying network delivers them securely and instantly to the right clinician.As care continues to extend beyond hospitals — into clinics, campuses, and homes — trusted connectivity becomes the foundation for patients to benefit fully from AI-enabled care. In the age of AI, the network is the critical infrastructure for the critical moments in healthcare.

## How can AI enhance the workforce experience in healthcare?

AI can dramatically improve the workforce experience by automating routine tasks, offering decision support, and enriching training — giving clinicians more time to focus on care.Generative AI scribes are already reducing the burden of note-taking. Predictive tools are improving staffing efficiency. And advanced simulations are strengthening skills for complex procedures, as we see in robotic surgery today.The challenge now is scale. To extend these benefits across every care setting — from operating rooms to home health — organizations need network infrastructure capable of handling high-compute, low-latency workloads securely and reliably.

MORE FOR YOU

As Dorai notes, the future of AI in healthcare will depend less on the brilliance of algorithms and more on the robustness of the systems that connect them. If AI is the brain of the new healthcare ecosystem, the network is its nervous system — transmitting intelligence safely, instantly, and reliably across every node of care.The hospitals, health plans, and systems that recognize this early will not only deliver smarter care — they’ll deliver fairer, faster, and more connected care. The age of AI in healthcare won’t be won by the best code, but by the best connectivity.

***Editor’s Note***: This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity and flow.

[Editorial Standards](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesstaff/article/forbes-editorial-values-and-standards/)[Reprints & Permissions](https://www.parsintl.com/publications/forbes/)
